TI Social Technology Interaction for Innovation Generation in a Propelling
   Middle East Country: The Development of LINKING Oman program
SO PROCEEDINGS OF THE 6TH EUROPEAN CONFERENCE ON INNOVATION AND
   ENTREPRENEURSHIP, VOL 1 AND 2
LA English
DT Proceedings Paper
CT 6th European Conference on Innovation and Entrepreneurship (ECIE)
CY SEP 15-16, 2011
CL Robert Gordon Univ, Aberdeen, SCOTLAND
HO Robert Gordon Univ
DE Social networks; communication for mobilization; social platforms;
   Innovation generation; national dialogue; Middle East
AB This paper aim to present a key program to foster innovation in one of the only two Sultanates in the world: the Sultanate of Oman. The recent development of the communication technology usage in the Middle East has lead to dramatic impact in tackling the challenges facing the entire region, especially amongst the growing young generations. The Sultanate of Oman, guided by a national plan with a long-term vision (i.e. Vision 2020), is aiming for capitalizing in ICT (Information Communication Technology) tools in order to foster research and innovation culture. Accordingly, the LINKING Oman Program (i.e. Linking International and National Knowledge for Innovation Generation in Oman) has been designed to encourage and facilitate the dialogue and collaboration between national and international stakeholders, fostering the innovation ecology in the country. Making use of the Communication for Mobilization theory (Bernardo Toro, 1996) and Information Communication Technologies, (in particular web 2.0 elements), the program was designed to promote an alliance between the technological and social efforts for innovation. What is more, it represents one of the key programs integrated within a governmental project (i.e The Innovation Hub) designed to provide a harmonized environment, with centrally shared resources for various innovation assistance programs in Oman. The importance of the program originates from the fact that all the minimum ingredients and requirements to initiate an innovation ecosystem in the country are in place, but a coherent national dialogue to make it happen is apparently missing. For instance, initial strategic studies showed that the proximity of the largest university to the largest Oman's Incubator, and industrial zones warrants the establishment of the best Science Park' in the Gulf Cooperation Council (GCC) region, but the effective linkages for the necessary dialogue are not visible. In a nut-shell, the LINKING Oman program is capitalizing on the current available local infrastructure, the nationally approved innovation programs and a realistic organizational stakeholder's capacity, in order to make the most of the offered technological tools, which include collaborative platforms, virtual reality labs and mentoring facilities. It is expected that the social component of the dialogue will be activated by best practices in communication for mobilization plans.
C1 [Al-Mukhaini, Abeer; Al-Mughairi, Mohammed] Res Council, Dev & Innovat Off, Muscat, Oman.

AU Dai, WH
   Chen, MQ
   Ye, N
AF Dai, Weihui
   Chen, Mingqi
   Ye, Nan
TI Research on the innovation system of China's software industry based on
   CAS theory
SO KYBERNETES
LA English
DT Article
DE Cybernetics; Innovation; Ecosystems; Computer software; China
AB Purpose - The purpose of this paper is to define and analyze the innovation system of China's software industry in order to build its innovation capability.
   Design/methodology/approach - From a complex adaptive systems (CAS) perspective, the authors researched the constitution and operating mechanism of China's software industry innovation system. By using methods and theories of CAS theory, the innovation problems of the software industry in China were analyzed and valuable suggestions put forth for its future development.
   Findings - Innovation system is one kind of complex systems and it has the characteristics of CAS.
   Research limitations/implications Quantitative analysis of the software industry innovation system should be emphasized in the next stage of research.
   Practical implications - The paper provides a new perspective and useful advice for technology policymakers.
   Originality/value - The paper applies CAS theory to the area of social management and provides a new approach to study industrial innovation systems.

TI Financing mechanisms for forest ecosystem services in Europe and their
   implications for forest governance
SO ALLGEMEINE FORST UND JAGDZEITUNG
LA English
DT Article
DE Market-based instruments; payments for environmental services;
   marketability; public and private goods; forest policy; innovation
   governance; innovation systems
AB A range of forest ecosystem services have public good characteristics and are therefore difficult to market. In recent years, a number of new financing mechanisms are gaining importance. This paper studies forest ecosystem services from the perspective of innovation research. In order to analyse financing approaches, it uses a classification scheme, which includes pure public mechanisms (taxes and subsidies), mixed public-private mechanisms (public-private contracts and market creation), and pure private mechanisms (trade of goods and services, land purchase and land lease, eco-sponsoring, donations and certification). It gives an overview of their use throughout Europe, based on a questionnaire survey conducted in 26 European Union countries. In this questionnaire, representatives of governments and other stakeholders from forestry and nature conservation, are asked which financing mechanisms are most frequently used and which they propose. While governments rather propose taxes and subsidies, the non-governmental actors call for contracts or market creation. It is remarkable that they do not promote more strongly pure private mechanisms. Also forest owners' representatives rather rely on state activity than their own marketing efforts which indicates that non-wood forest ecosystem services are not seen as a business field.
   Applying an innovation system approach, the paper discusses the implications of the use of financing mechanisms for forest governance. We observe a paradoxical development regarding the roles of public institutions in forest governance: Although authorities increasingly use market-based instruments and partly retreat from advisory function, they gain more roles in the provision of forest ecosystem services. On the one hand, a stronger use of market-based instruments is part of the trend to a more explicit involvement of private actors into the governance of natural resources. On the other hand, public institutions receive new tasks in order to promote the development of private financing mechanisms as examples of innovations for providing ecosystem services.
   New tasks lie in the promotion and support of innovative activities in the sector but also in institutional innovations. The public policy instruments such as subsidies need improvement; the state is called for creating new market schemes; and public institutions have a role in supporting the forming of cooperative structures of land owners or across sectors. By this, the roles of public institutions definitely change: the traditional division of state and market spheres increasingly breaks up and new modes of governance appear in which the state involves private actors but at the same time takes over more responsibilities also in the development of markets.
C1 [Weiss, Gerhard] Univ Nat Resources & Life Sci, Dept Econ & Social Sci, Inst Forest Environm & Nat Resource Policy, Cent E European Reg Off,European Forest Inst EFIC, A-1180 Vienna, Austria.

AU Liu, Y

GP IEEE
TI Construction and Evaluation of an Feasible Target System for Industry
   Cluster's Innovation Ecosystem Based on Intellectual Property Rights
SO 2011 INTERNATIONAL CONFERENCE ON ELECTRONICS, COMMUNICATIONS AND CONTROL
   (ICECC)
LA English
DT Proceedings Paper
CT IEEE International Conference on Electronics, Communications and Control
   (ICECC)
CY SEP 09-11, 2011
CL Ningbo, PEOPLES R CHINA
SP IEEE, Ningbo Univ, Key Lab Sci & Tech Natl Def (KLSTND)
DE intellectual property rights; industrial cluster; innovation ecosystem;
   target system; evaluation method
AB On the basis of intellectual property rights and research results on the innovation ecosystems for industrial clusters, the present research established five primary targets and 20 secondary targets from five aspects: innovative environment, innovation resource, innovation management, innovation outputs, and innovation performance. This study constructed a multi-level evaluation model for the industry cluster innovation ecosystems on the basis of fuzzy mathematics. This model will provide a valid method for the scientific assessment of the effects of industrial cluster innovation ecosystems.

AU Bers, JA
   Dismukes, JP
   Mehserle, D

TI Extending the Stage-Gate-System (R) Model to Radical Innovation: The
   Accelerated Radical Innovation Model
SO 2011 PROCEEDINGS OF PICMET 11: TECHNOLOGY MANAGEMENT IN THE ENERGY-SMART
   WORLD (PICMET)
LA English
DT Proceedings Paper
CT Portland International Center for Management of Engineering and
   Technology (PICMET) Conference on Technology Management in the
   Energy-Smart World
CY JUL 31-AUG 04, 2011
CL Portland, OR
SP Portland State Univ, Maseeh Coll Engn & Comp Sci, Dept Engn & Technol Management, Portland State Univ, Off Informat Technol, IKON Off Solut
ID NETWORKS; SYSTEMS
AB For new product development in established organizations, the Stage-Gate model is a widely accepted method for managing the three key factors of time, resources and risk. But for radical innovation, which is further out on the time-resource-risk curve and which may occur in either start-up or established firms, the innovator must simultaneously navigate a more complex space comprised of four environments: market-societal, technological-scientific, business and organizational, and the innovation ecosystem; and craft within this space a new business model, business systems and processes, a corporate strategy, an organization, and a value network. To address this more complex environment, the authors propose to extend Stage-Gate with a new approach, Accelerated Radical Innovation (ARI), which guides the innovator through the Stage-Gate stages across these four environments. The model also builds in additional stages needed to accommodate the extended time frame of radical innovation, such as strategy development, organizational design, and several periods of pre-inception and post-launch development. But to conserve the innovator's limited time/attention resources in this more complex environment, the ARI modal preserves the fundamental premise of Stage-Gate-partitioning the innovation process into stages so that downstream/second-order activities are deferred until first-order issues have been resolved. The theory and logic of ARI model is explained, and the model is now being tested through application to three ongoing radical innovations in the fields of medicine, environmental engineering, and electronics, and in the design and development of a university engineering management curriculum.

TI Adoption Dynamics of Increasing-Return Technologies in Systemic Contexts
SO 2011 PROCEEDINGS OF PICMET 11: TECHNOLOGY MANAGEMENT IN THE ENERGY-SMART
   WORLD (PICMET)
LA English
DT Proceedings Paper
CT Portland International Center for Management of Engineering and
   Technology (PICMET) Conference on Technology Management in the
   Energy-Smart World
CY JUL 31-AUG 04, 2011
CL Portland, OR
SP Portland State Univ, Maseeh Coll Engn & Comp Sci, Dept Engn & Technol Management, Portland State Univ, Off Informat Technol, IKON Off Solut
ID CONSUMER DURABLES; COMPUTER INDUSTRY; DOMINANT DESIGNS; PRODUCT GROWTH;
   INNOVATION; MARKET; DETERMINANTS; MODULARITY; FRAMEWORK; EVOLUTION
AB This paper examines the adoption dynamics of increasing-return technologies in a systemic business ecosystem context. Many systemic, complex technologies have shown to exhibit increasing returns to adoption in that the initial increase in adoption leads to increasing experience with the technology and improvements in technology and its utilization which further lead to increasing adoption. In systemic context our empirical study examines the adoption dynamics of technology utilization provisioned by another sub-system industry's actors. We hypothesize that the more a technology is utilized initially the faster the adoption would be due to experience gained in utilizing technology. Simultaneously, we hypothesize that as the technologies become more complex as they build on existing knowledge, the dynamics of adoption would slow down since the experience accumulation becomes more difficult and resource consuming. Our original empirical setting considers some 2890 products utilizing 54 different technologies and platforms in the computer industry. Our modeling results show that, technological improvements between successive technologies influences the companies' adoption of the successive technology in a way that the more there is improvement performance-wise, the less the firms adopt the technology. However, we also find some anomalies contrary to our initial expectations and discuss the managerial and research implications.
C1 [Makinen, Saku J.; Kanniainen, Juho; Dedehayir, Ozgur] Tampere Univ Technol, Dept Ind Management, CITER Ctr Innovat & Technol Res, FIN-33101 Tampere, Finland.

RI makinen, saku/G-4352-2014

SO DIGITAL FACTORY FOR HUMAN-ORIENTED PRODUCTION SYSTEMS: THE INTEGRATION
   OF INTERNATIONAL RESEARCH PROJECTS
LA English
DT Article; Book Chapter
ID FIRM
AB Business Process Management can be considered a powerful catalyst to increase companies' innovation capabilities by exploiting and coordinating firms' processes and resources in an optimal way. In a digital factory, processes do not only require useful information as input but also the possibility to capture, share, and reuse knowledge to increase workers productivity. As a consequence, there is a current need to evolve from old generation factories that exchange information among specific or closed working groups and/or individuals in silos to the next generation of digital- and knowledge-based factories where relevant business processes content is coauthored and shared among all workers. Additionally, companies need to collaborate with distributed internal and external networks to carry out different processes in a collaborative and concurrent way, in particular with customers and suppliers. On the other hand, Web 2.0 functionalities, such as wilds, blogs, tags, among many others, promise a new digital business ecosystem enabling formal/informal and internal/external relationships and interactions. Thus, this chapter briefly presents the applied research carried out in the Swiss DiFac project by SUPSI and CEMEX Research Group to cocreate the SMARTBRICKS Web 2.0 prototype to foster an open-collaborative space for business processes knowledge sharing and contents cocreation.

SO PROCEEDINGS OF THE 18TH INTERNATIONAL CONFERENCE ON ENGINEERING DESIGN

SE International Conference on Engineering Design
LA English
DT Proceedings Paper
CT 18th International Conference on Engineering Design (ICED)
CY AUG 15-18, 2011
CL Tech Univ Denmark (DTU), Copenhagen, DENMARK
SP Tech Univ Denmark (DTU), Dept Management Engn, Sect Engn Design & Prod Dev, Design Soc
HO Tech Univ Denmark (DTU)
DE Business ecosystem; requirement interdependency; productivity
   interrelation
ID STRATEGIES; INNOVATION; COMPETITION; ECOLOGY
AB Recent dramatic changes in a mobile industry, initiated by smart phones, are drawing enormous attention to business ecosystems. A perspective to view firms as members of cross-industry ecosystem was first suggested by Moore [1] for describing co-evolution behavior in high-technology business areas. Although an ecosystem has been pervasive in any industry at any time, today's eco-systems are getting more horizontal and complex. This study develops a representation model of such complex ecosystems and a framework for analyzing interrelated productivity of ecosystem members. The proposed model especially emphasizes interdependency between product and service offerings that ecosystem members cooperatively deliver. This interdependency determines the interrelation between members' productivity, and finally sustainability of a whole ecosystem. This study describes a general procedure for representing and analyzing an ecosystem and discusses the difference between the traditional and smart phone mobile ecosystems based on the result of the analysis.

TI City Innovative Ecosystem Analysis
SO PROCEEDINGS OF THE 4TH CONFERENCE ON SYSTEMS SCIENCE, MANAGEMENT SCIENCE
   AND SYSTEMS DYNAMICS, SSMSSD10, VOL 4

HO Donghua Univ
DE innovative; creative; ecological system; theory; system
AB Watanabe divides the human society into industrial society, the information society, and the ubiquitous society. The ubiquitous requires a shift from function oriented to solution oriented trajectory corresponding to seamless, all actors participation and on demand institutions, which is quite similar to an evolutional ecosystem. To achieve this ubiquitous society we need a collaboration of innovation activities and innovative institutions. In this paper, we traced the origin of theory of innovative ecosystem, presented the status quo, and cluster it into five groups, including environment of innovative system, innovative engine of innovative system, formation of innovative system, characteristics of innovative ecosystem, and other aspect of innovative ecosystem. The conclusion is that, innovative environmental aspects is the core of innovative ecosystem, and innovative networks aspect is not very overall, such as the existing position of the government is ignored. Therefore, innovation ecosystem theory is lacking of a complete system to assess its features, functions and performance comprehensively.

TI USING KNOWBOTS IN DEVELOPING KNOWLEDGE ECOSYSTEMS
SO PROCEEDINGS OF THE 6TH INTERNATIONAL CONFERENCE ON BUSINESS EXCELLENCE,
   VOL 2
LA English
DT Proceedings Paper
CT 6th International Conference on Business Excellence
CY OCT 14-15, 2011
CL Brasov, ROMANIA
SP Soc Business Excellence
DE cognitive process; knowbots; knowledge ecosystems
AB The paper describes the structure of knowledge ecosystem based on knowbots, as well as the role of knowbots in the process of developing ecosystems. There are presented and analyzed the connections which are formed within ecosystems by using models based on agents. One of the objectives of digital ecosystems consist of overcoming the existing barriers and promoting innovative forms of software creation, knowledge sharing and creating the communities, thus allowing long term growth and competitiveness of small and medium enterprises. The objective of achieving self-organization in the digital ecosystem suggests the necessity of a capacity of superior reproduction of parts with minimum intervention from human agents, thus increasing the number of difficulties regarding quality control. Knowledge ecosystems require strategic engagement and managerial skill with the goal of combining information facilities of intelligent assistance with consolidated organizational practices for innovation, learning and interactive partnership. As an expanding field, applications of information technology and communications are still far from having reached their maximum potential. The behaviour of human agents is based on cognitive processes. After analyzing cognitive processes, the results may be relevant both for the construction of intelligent agents and for establishing appropriate correspondences with neurobiological processes.

DE Circular economy; Technical Innovation; agriculture; dissipative
   structure
AB To follow the "3R" principals, and develop agriculture under the guidance of the idea of circular economy has become an important principal of economy development in many countries. This places higher demands on optimization of agriculture technical innovation system, exploration of new paths and improvement of agriculture pattern that depends on resources consumption. Based on complexity theory and the idea of circular economy, this article suggested a multi-objective agriculture technical innovation pattern. Objectives like people's health and safety of ecosystem and environment are covered in it.

AU Samila, S
   Sorenson, O
AF Samila, Sampsa
   Sorenson, Olav
TI Venture capital as a catalyst to commercialization
SO RESEARCH POLICY
LA English
DT Article
DE R&D; Research grants; Science; Innovation; Patenting; Entrepreneurship
ID RESEARCH-AND-DEVELOPMENT; SUBSIDIES STIMULATE; INNOVATION; SCIENCE;
   INDUSTRY; INDICATORS; CITATIONS; SYSTEMS; FIRMS
AB We find that the public funding of academic research and venture capital have a complementary relationship in fostering innovation and the creation of new firms Using panel data on metropolitan areas in the United States from 1993 to 2002 our analyses reveal that the positive relationships between government research grants to universities and research institutes and the rates of patenting and firm formation in a region become more pronounced as the supply of venture capital in that region Increases Our results remain robust to estimation with an Instrumental variable to address potential endogeneity in the provision of venture capital Consistent with perspectives that emphasize the importance of an innovation ecosystem our findings point to a strong interaction between private financial intermediation and public research funding in promoting entrepreneurship and innovation (C) 2010 Elsevier B V All rights reserved

PT J
AU Adner, R
   Kapoor, R
AF Adner, Ron
   Kapoor, Rahul
TI VALUE CREATION IN INNOVATION ECOSYSTEMS: HOW THE STRUCTURE OF
   TECHNOLOGICAL INTERDEPENDENCE AFFECTS FIRM PERFORMANCE IN NEW TECHNOLOGY
   GENERATIONS
SO STRATEGIC MANAGEMENT JOURNAL
LA English
DT Article
DE technological change; first mover advantage; business ecosystem;
   vertical integration; complements; semiconductor lithography
ID CHEMICAL-PROCESSING INDUSTRIES; DEMAND-BASED PERSPECTIVE;
   DIVISION-OF-LABOR; COMPETITIVE ADVANTAGE; 1ST-MOVER ADVANTAGE;
   LEARNING-CURVE; LIFE-CYCLES; SURVIVAL; EVOLUTION; DYNAMICS
AB The success of an innovating firm often depends on the efforts of other innovators in its environment. How do the challenges faced by external innovators affect the focal firm's outcomes? To address this question we first characterize the external environment according to the structure Of interdependence. We follow the flow of inputs and outputs in the ecosystem to distinguish between upstream components that tire handled by the focal firm, and downstream complements that are bundled by the firm's customers. We hypothesize that the effects of external innovation challenges depend not only on their magnitude, but also 017 their location in the ecosystem relative to the focal firm. We identify a key asymmetry that results from the location of challenges relative to a focal firm-greater upstream innovation challenges in components enhance the benefits that accrue to technology leaders, while greater downstream innovation challenges in complements erode these benefits. We,further propose that the effectiveness of vertical integration as a strategy to manage ecosystem interdependence increases over the course of the technology life cycle. Me explore these arguments in the context of the global semiconductor lithography equipment industry from its emergence in 1962 to 2005 across nine distinct technology generations. We find strong empirical support for our framework. Copyright (C) 2009 John Wiley & Sons, Ltd.

PT J
AU Lichtenthaler, U
AF Lichtenthaler, Ulrich
TI Determinants of proactive and reactive technology licensing: A
   contingency perspective
SO RESEARCH POLICY
LA English
DT Article
DE Technology licensing; Technology exploitation; Markets for technology;
   Appropriability; Open innovation
ID INTELLECTUAL PROPERTY; ORGANIZATIONAL BOUNDARIES; EMPIRICAL-ANALYSIS;
   PATENT PROTECTION; FIRMS STRATEGIES; INNOVATION; MARKET; KNOWLEDGE;
   INDUSTRY; DIVERSIFICATION
AB Industrial firms increasingly attempt to license their technologies apart from applying them in their own products. Because of the imperfections in technology markets, an active approach towards technology licensing does not automatically result in licensing transactions. To balance prior research, which has focused on licensing transactions as the outcome of licensing intentions, we take a contingency view to analyze how characteristics of a firm's innovation ecosystem determine different strategic types of licensing. Specifically, we distinguish proactive licensing, which refers to identifying recipients for technology transactions, and reactive licensing, which relates to offering licenses to infringers of a firm's intellectual property. Survey data show that environmental antecedents concerning appropriability, i.e., patent protection and technological turbulence, and determinants regarding technology markets, i.e., transaction frequency and competitive intensity, have different effects on proactive and reactive licensing. On this basis, the article has major implications for research into technology licensing, markets for technology, and open innovation. (C) 2009 Elsevier B.V. All rights reserved.
C1 WHU Otto Beisheim Sch Management Technol & Innova, Dept Technol & Innovat Management, D-56179 Vallendar, Germany.
RP Lichtenthaler, U (reprint author), WHU Otto Beisheim Sch Management Technol & Innova, Dept Technol & Innovat Management, Burgpl 2, D-56179 Vallendar, Germany.
EM lichtenthaler@whu.edu

TI Study on the Innovative System Governance Mechanism of High-tech
   Enterprises on the Basis of Ecology
SO ADVANCES IN ASIA-PACIFIC LOW CARBON ECONOMY
LA English
DT Proceedings Paper
CT International Conference of Asia-Pacific Low Carbon Economy/9th
   Northeast Asia Academic Network
CY NOV 26-27, 2010
CL Changsha, PEOPLES R CHINA
DE high-tech enterprises; innovative ecosystem; governance mechanism
AB Innovation of high-tech enterprises can be taken as an eco-evolutionary system, a coexistent innovation system linked by technical standards. Effective operation of innovative ecosystem depends on whether the governance mechanism can ensure partners to have enough motives not to take advantage of their asymmetric information and incomplete contract to seek personal gains. To prevent such opportunistic behaviors as hold-up behavior, pick-up behavior, withdrawal menace, concealment and false release of information, etc. caused by asymmetric information of the innovative ecosystem, the innovative ecosystem governance mechanism of high-tech enterprises is studied and demonstrated respectively in terms of the decision-making mechanism, negotiation and coordination mechanism, platform pricing mechanism, and constraint mechanism, etc.

TI Concept Refinement and Redefinition of Innovation
SO APPLICATION AND BEST PRACTICE OF COMPETITIVE TECHNICAL INTELLIGENCE
LA English
DT Proceedings Paper
CT Proceedings of International Conference on Technological Innovation and
   Competitive Technical Intelligence 2010
CY DEC 03-05, 2010
CL Peking Univ, Beijing, PEOPLES R CHINA
SP Peking Univ, Beijing Acad Sci & Technol
HO Peking Univ
DE Innovation; Technical innovation; Innovation ecology
AB This article starts with an analysis of the concept of innovation, and argues that at the core of the concept is value realization. Secondly, it analyzes the technology-driven linear innovation model, demand-pull linear innovation model, synchronous coupled model, interactive model, network model chain and the dynamic interactive innovation model. Finally, this article proposes the ecosystem of innovation, on the bases of analyzing innovation system theories. Innovation is an extremely powerful, dynamic interaction system, and there is great uncertainty in the system.

TI Options for Customer Integration in the Open Innovation Paradigm at
   Deutsche Telekom
SO APPLIED TECHNOLOGY AND INNOVATION MANAGEMENT: INSIGHTS AND EXPERIENCES
   FROM AN INDUSTRY-LEADING INNOVATION CENTRE
LA English
DT Article; Book Chapter
AB The consistent application of the open innovation logic leads to the inclusion of the customer Open innovation helps to open tip company boundaries, promoting cooperation with and integration of external know-how brokers to meet the more exacting innovation ecosystem requirements. In addition to subsidiaries, suppliers, competitors, consultants, as well as private and public research institutions; first and foremost, the customer plays a decisive role (Eurostat 2007).
   Customers are equal partners in the development processes of Deutsche Telekom as part of a consistent open innovation approach. The four customer integration methods - lead user method, ideas competition, virtual communities, and "toolkits for innovation" - are based on theoretical principles and are exemplary for user integration in the open innovation approach.
C1 [Arnold, Heinrich; Erner, Michael; Moeckel, Peter] Deutsch Telekom AG Labs, D-10587 Berlin, Germany.
   [Schlaeffer, Christopher] Deutsch Telekom AG, D-53227 Bonn, Germany.
RP Arnold, H (reprint author), Deutsch Telekom AG Labs, Ernst Reuter Pl 7, D-10587 Berlin, Germany.

TI Social Network Analysis of the Irish Biotech Industry: Implications for

SO DIGITAL ECOSYSTEMS

LA English
DT Proceedings Paper
CT 3rd International OPAALS Conference
CY MAR 22-23, 2010
CL IPTI, Aracaju, BRAZIL
HO IPTI
DE Digital Ecosystems; Social network analysis; Innovation; Biotech
ID SMALL-WORLD; KNOWLEDGE; CLUSTERS; DYNAMICS
AB This paper presents an analysis of the socio-spatial structures of innovation, collaboration and knowledge flow among SMEs in the Irish biotech sector. The study applies social network analysis to determine the structure of networks of company directors and inventors in the biotech sector. In addition, the article discusses the implications of the findings for the role and contours of a biotech digital ecosystem. To distil these lessons, the research team organised a seminar which was attended by representatives of biotech actors and experts.

TI Digital Ecosystem for Knowledge, Learning and Exchange: Exploring
   Socio-technical Concepts and Adoption
SO DIGITAL ECOSYSTEMS
SE Lecture Notes of the Institute for Computer Sciences Social Informatics
   and Telecommunications Engineering
LA English
DT Proceedings Paper
CT 3rd International OPAALS Conference
CY MAR 22-23, 2010
CL IPTI, Aracaju, BRAZIL
HO IPTI
DE Digital Ecosystems; Knowledge; Learning; Socio-Technical Systems;
   Agriculture Innovation in India
ID MANAGEMENT; HIERARCHY; CREATION
AB Knowledge is an indispensable element that ensures healthy functioning of any socio-technical system. Despite a terminological ambiguity, it is discussed by many researchers. Learning is a process to seek and recreate knowledge within socio-technical systems. In this paper we attempt to explicate the terminological ambiguities of knowledge and explore knowledge processing and creation cycles as relevant for socio-technical systems. Further we present insights about theories of learning discussed by different scholars. We extend the paper towards new models of knowledge exchange inspired by and flow inspired by digital ecosystem concepts.

AU Amarilli, F

AF Amarilli, Fabrizio
   Spreafico, Alberto
BE Passiante, G
TI Tisettanta case study: the interoperation of furniture production
   companies
SO EVOLVING TOWARDS THE INTERNETWORKED ENTERPRISE: TECHNOLOGICAL AND
   ORGANIZATIONAL PERSPECTIVES
LA English
DT Article; Book Chapter
AB This chapter presents the Tisettanta case study, focusing on the definition of the possible innovations that ICT technologies can bring to the Italian wood-furniture industry. This sector is characterized by industrial clusters composed mainly of a few large companies with international brand reputations and a large base of SMEs that manufacture finished products or are specialized in the production of single components/processes (such as the Brianza cluster, where Tisettanta operates). In this particular business ecosystem, ICT technologies can bring relevant support and improvements to the supply chain process, where collaborations between enterprises are put into action through the exchange of business documents such as orders, order confirmation, bills of lading, invoices, etc. The analysis methodology adopted in the Tisettanta case study refers to the TEKNE Methodology of Change (see Chapter 2), which defines a framework for supporting firms in the adoption of the Internetworked Enterprise organizational paradigm.

TI The Study of Family Business Ecosystem
SO IFERA AT CHINA 2010 FAMILY BUSINESS FORUM: OPPORTUNITIES AND CHALLENGES
   OF FAMILY BUSINESS
LA English
DT Proceedings Paper
CT IFERA 2010 Family Business Forum
CY JAN 13-15, 2010
CL Zhuhai, PEOPLES R CHINA
SP Int Family Enterprise Res Acad, Beijning Inst Technol
DE Family enterprises; Sustainable development; Family business ecosystem
AB In this paper, considering the characteristics of family businesses, we propose the concept of the family ecosystem, then analyze its contents and characteristics, finally present two approaches to build the family business ecosystem. On one hand, family enterprise can be established as the core of the business ecosystem: on the other hand, they can join the existing business ecosystems, through a variety of business ecosystems to achieve synergies between the competing developments of co-governance. In this paper, the issue of family enterprise business ecosystem can provide with a view and inspiration to sustainable development and innovation of strategies for family business theory.

PT J
AU Ginsberg, A

TI Ecosystem Strategies for Complex Technological Innovation: The Case of
   Smart Grid Development
SO PICMET 2010: TECHNOLOGY MANAGEMENT FOR GLOBAL ECONOMIC GROWTH
LA English
DT Proceedings Paper
CT Portland International Center for Management of Engineering and
   Technology (PICMET 10)
CY 2010
CL Natl Elect & Comp Technol Ctr (NECTEC), Natl Sci & Technol Dev Agcy
   (NSTDA, Portland, OR
SP Natl Sci Technol & Innovation Policy Off (STI), Siam Cement Grp (SCG), Bangkok Bank, CAT Telecom, Western Digital, IEEE, King Mongkuts Univ Technol Thonbury, Thammasat Univ, Mahidol Univ
HO Natl Elect & Comp Technol Ctr (NECTEC), Natl Sci & Technol Dev Agcy (NSTDA
ID FIRMS
AB This paper deals generally with the creation, structuring and behavior of innovation ecosystems, i.e. a network of diverse actors, including emerging young firms, as well as established medium-size and large enterprises, NGOs, and government. More specifically, the paper explores these basic issues using the example of smart grid development, which is now taking place in the cleantech/renewable energy field. To examine and compare smart grid innovation ecosystems being assembled by GE, IBM and Cisco Systems, our study assembles data on ecosystem membership, provides metrics on key parameters, and generates "maps" of these smart grid innovation ecosystems. These ecosystems are also analyzed and compared using social networking analysis, focusing in particular on the parameters of diversity, centrality (degree, betweenness and closeness) and density. Generally, our results show that innovation ecosystem strategies constitute a key approach for entering and innovating in the smart grid arena.

AU Boon-Kwee, N
   Thiruchelvam, K
AF Boon-Kwee, Ng
   Thiruchelvam, K.
BE Rawani, AM
   Kettani, H
   Lian, Z
TI Technological Innovation in Malaysian Small and Medium-sized Wooden
   Furniture Manufacturers: Actors and Linkages
SO PROCEEDINGS OF 2010 INTERNATIONAL CONFERENCE ON INNOVATION, MANAGEMENT
   AND SERVICE
LA English
DT Proceedings Paper
CT 2010 International Conference on Innovation, Management and Service
CY FEB 26-28, 2010
CL Singapore, SINGAPORE
SP IACSIT, Management Sci & Engn Soc
DE technological innovation; wooden furniture industry; SMEs; Malaysia
AB Innovation ecosystem at the sectoral-level is constituted of heterogeneous actors, which are highly idiosyncratic and linked in various ways through market and non-market relationships. Effective linkages among the main actors of such an innovation system are vital in strengthening the firms' technological innovation capabilities. Such linkages contribute towards, among others, accessing scientific and technological information, securing project funding and establishing research partnerships. This study empirically reviews the current technological innovation trends among SMEs in Malaysia's wooden furniture industry, particularly the roles of actors as well as their linkages patterns. The findings from the study reveal that the existing linkages in the industry are mainly focused on the immediate business environment, such as clients, suppliers and competitors. Universities, government organizations and public research institutes are not represented in these linkages. The study submits that policymakers need to redefine the existing industrial linkage programmes in order to enhance the linkages between the furniture SMEs and the public sector organizations.
C1 [Boon-Kwee, Ng; Thiruchelvam, K.] Univ Malaya, Dept Sci & Technol Studies, Kuala Lumpur 50603, Malaysia.

We summarize the problems of industrial innovation ecosystem in the current period of brand promotion, and points out that external environment and coordination, which are needed by the core innovative elements, vary with the innovative sequences of each stage.

TI Study on Technology Innovation Management of R&D Teams in Enterprises
   with NK Model
SO PROCEEDINGS OF THE 2010 INTERNATIONAL CONFERENCE ON TECHNOLOGY
   INNOVATION AND INDUSTRY DEVELOPMENT
LA English
DT Proceedings Paper
CT International Conference on Technology Innovation and Industry
   Development
CY SEP 17-18, 2010
CL Yantai, PEOPLES R CHINA
SP Shandong Inst Business & Technol, M & D Forum
DE R&D team; technology innovation; innovation management; fitness
   landscape; NK model
AB Technology innovation (TI) management is very important for improving innovation performance of R&D teams in enterprises. As the technology innovation system is akin to evolving ecosystem, the fitness landscape theory can effectively describe the status of technology innovation management (TIM) based on NK model. Through the empirical investigation into R&D teams of some enterprises located in Shandong province, the interactions and coupling relations among impact factors on fitness of TIM are discussed, the roles on the improving the innovation performance played by the fitness landscape theory and NK model are analyzed.

PT S
AU O'Connor, SM
AF O'Connor, Sean M.
BE Libecap, GD
   Thursby, M
   Hoskinson, S
TI NAVIGATING THE ISSUES OF MULTIDISCIPLINARY STUDENT TEAMS SERVING
   UNIVERSITY SPIN-OFFS
SO SPANNING BOUNDARIES AND DISCIPLINES: UNIVERSITY TECHNOLOGY
   COMMERCIALIZATION IN THE IDEA AGE
SE Advances in the Study of Entrepreneurship Innovation and Economic Growth
LA English
DT Article; Book Chapter
AB Improving the commercialization of university research has become a national priority. Most existing programs focus on training and supporting faculty and students to be the entrepreneur. However, programs are also needed to train and support those who will serve the entrepreneur. This chapter asserts that professionals with specific expertise in serving entrepreneurs are a critical, yet overlooked, part of the "innovation ecosystem" necessary to commercialize university research. It provides an overview of the Entrepreneurial Law Clinic at the University of Washington, which provides a multidisciplinary teaching, research, and service platform that assists University spin-offs while developing the next generation innovation ecosystem. Bringing together law, business, and engineering students to work with tech transfer licensing officers and faculty researchers to spin off a university technology involves many challenges. Yet, it can be done and the benefits are manifold. This chapter outlines three key issues for this kind of program. First, who is the client: the tech transfer office or the faculty researcher? Second, how to mediate among the different visions for how to commercialize the technology through the spin-off - including whether the technology is ready for commercialization or needs to undergo further translational work. And third, how to ensure that all the different students are being properly supervised and that all project members are keeping appropriate confidentiality toward the technology and business plans. The chapter shows how the missteps, conflicts, and confusion that naturally arise for each team project actually provide the best teaching moments for team members, supervisors, and faculty alike.

PT J
AU Rohrbeck, R
   Holzle, K
   Gemunden, HG
AF Rohrbeck, Rene
   Hoelzle, Katharina
   Gemuenden, Hans Georg
TI Opening up for competitive advantage - How Deutsche Telekom creates an
   open innovation ecosystem
SO R & D MANAGEMENT
LA English
DT Article
ID RESEARCH-AND-DEVELOPMENT; PRODUCT DEVELOPMENT; FRONT-END; TECHNOLOGY;
   USERS; CHALLENGES; TOOLKITS; PROCTER; SUCCESS; MODEL
AB When, on 21st September 2006, 'The Economist' compared incumbent telecommunication operators with dinosaurs that could soon face extinction, most readers were ready to agree. The mixture of declining revenues and fierce competition was believed to shake the market and soon to dethrone former national champions. However, there are ways to fight that extinction and one way is to open up for competitive advantage. This paper reflects on a case study at Deutsche Telekom, the German national telecommunication operator. The aim of this study is to analyse to what extent the open innovation paradigm has been embraced inside this now multinational company. Using empirical evidence from 15 in-depth interviews, we identify 11 open innovation instruments and detail their value contribution. We can show that Deutsche Telekom has successfully enhanced its innovation capacity by opening up its traditional development process and embracing external creativity and knowledge resources.
C1 [Rohrbeck, Rene] Tech Univ Berlin, Inst Deutsch Telekom Labs, D-10587 Berlin, Germany.
   [Hoelzle, Katharina; Gemuenden, Hans Georg] Tech Univ Berlin, D-10623 Berlin, Germany.

PT J
AU Li, YR

TI The technological roadmap of Cisco's business ecosystem
SO TECHNOVATION
LA English
DT Article
DE Cisco; Business ecosystem; Mergers and acquisitions (M&A); Patent
   analysis; Text mining; Technological roadmap
ID OPEN INNOVATION; COMPETITION; INDUSTRY; ECOLOGY; SYSTEMS; MODELS
AB A business ecosystem provides a new perspective for repositioning a company's strategy in order to aggressively further its own interests and to promote its overall ecosystem health. Analyzing a business ecosystem is not an easy task, and therefore only a few studies have been made, even though some scholars and managers accept this concept from ecology since value creation is achieved by establishing a platform that other members of the ecosystem can use to enhance their performance. This paper presents a case study based on both qualitative and quantitative data, by explaining how Cisco Systems has been so successful in utilizing its strategy of mergers and acquisitions (M&A) for corporate growth based on a business ecosystem, especially from a technological perspective. We use US patent data from 1993 to 2005 to illustrate Cisco's technological roadmap. Finally, implications of symbiosis, platform, and co-evolution are provided for managers to challenge the contemporary business environment. (C) 2009 Elsevier Ltd. All rights reserved.

PT J
AU Papaioannou, T
   Wield, D
   Chataway, J
AF Papaioannou, Theo
   Wield, David
   Chataway, Joanna
TI Knowledge ecologies and ecosystems? An empirically grounded reflection
   on recent developments in innovation systems theory
SO ENVIRONMENT AND PLANNING C-GOVERNMENT AND POLICY
LA English
DT Article; Proceedings Paper
CT 6th Triple Helix International Conference
CY MAY 16-18, 2007
CL Singapore, SINGAPORE
ID BIOSCIENCE MEGACENTRES; INDUSTRY ORGANIZATION; ECONOMIC-GEOGRAPHY;
   BIOTECHNOLOGY; FIRMS; COLLABORATION; CAPABILITIES; DYNAMICS; EUROPE;
   BIRTH
AB Recent academic and policy debate on innovation indicates that there has been some shift from a more traditional systems approach to ecologies and ecosystems. The later are concepts transferred from the world of biology to the social world in order to explain the evolutionary nature of interrelations between different individuals, their innovative activities, and their environment. We evaluate the concept of knowledge ecology and the theory of innovation ecosystem oil two Fundamental grounds; firstly, on the grounds of theoretical plausibility and conceptual consistency secondly, oil empirical grounds of the case of public-private interrelations of biotech innovation in Cambridge. The argument is that the concept of knowledge ecology and the theory of innovation ecosystems can lead to problems of reductionism and functionalism. This is due to their development in abstraction From more grounded analysis of historical processes of the social division of labour. Knowledge and innovation need to be looked at in the context of historically founded processes of socioeconomic development.

PT S
AU Dreher, C
   Reiners, T
   Dreher, N
   Dreher, H
AF Dreher, Carl
   Reiners, Torsten
   Dreher, Naomi
   Dreher, Heinz
GP IEEE
TI 3D Virtual Worlds as Collaborative Communities Enriching Human
   Endeavours: Innovative Applications in e-Learning
SO 2009 3RD IEEE INTERNATIONAL CONFERENCE ON DIGITAL ECOSYSTEMS AND
   TECHNOLOGIES
SE IEEE International Conference on Digital Ecosystems and Technologies
LA English
DT Proceedings Paper
CT 3rd IEEE International Conference on Digital Ecosystems and Technologies
CY JUN 01-03, 2009
CL Istanbul, TURKEY
SP IEEE
DE 3D Virtual Worlds; 3D Digital Ecosystems; Information Systems education;
   Information systems research
AB 3D Virtual Worlds are potent Digital Ecosystems because the 3D interface simulates real-world environments and the community of users creates a dynamic, real-to-life economy and in-world culture. Some Virtual Worlds such as Second Life empower users to generate in-world content through object building tools and programming languages; indeed the content in Second Life is entirely user-generated. This promotes a rich culture of innovation surrounding this emerging technology that continually develops the capabilities of the 3D Digital Ecosystem. The collaborative culture spans both the 3D in-world environment and 2D ecosystems; for example, Web 2.0 applications such as wikis and blogs facilitate support, discussion, and documentation for user-generated innovations. Innovation in 3D Digital Ecosystems such as Second Life are applied to all domains of human endeavour that exist in the real-world, including recreation, socialisation, commerce, and education. This paper shares the authors' professional experience using Second Life in tertiary Information Systems/Science education. Case studies describe the specific applications. They are followed by discussion of the benefits of 3D Digital Ecosystems for education and suggestions for future research, development, and practice.
C1 [Dreher, Carl; Reiners, Torsten; Dreher, Naomi; Dreher, Heinz] Curtin Univ Technol, Perth, WA 6845, Australia.

AU Botto, F
   Szabo, CA
AF Botto, Francesco
   Szabo, Csaba A.
GP IEEE
TI Digital Community Ecosystems: Through a New and Sustainable Local DE
   Development Strategy
SO 2009 3RD IEEE INTERNATIONAL CONFERENCE ON DIGITAL ECOSYSTEMS AND
   TECHNOLOGIES
SE IEEE International Conference on Digital Ecosystems and Technologies
LA English
DT Proceedings Paper
CT 3rd IEEE International Conference on Digital Ecosystems and Technologies
CY JUN 01-03, 2009
CL Istanbul, TURKEY
SP IEEE
DE Digital Ecosystem; Community Network; Socio-Technical Infrastructure;
   Business Model; Participation
AB When studying Digital Ecosystems infrastructures we usually consider the peer-to-peer network and the other elements of the service-oriented infrastructure. This paper opens the discussion on DE infrastructures by considering DEs as regional broadband innovations that should both interact with other innovations, like Community Networks, and be recreated from participatory projects. We therefore overcome the definition of DE as technological substrate, adopting a socio-technical perspective on infrastructures that opens the discussion on how develop Digital Community Ecosystems.

AU Dreher, C

   Dreher, N
   Dreher, H
AF Dreher, Carl
   Reiners, Torsten
   Dreher, Naomi

GP IEEE
TI 3D Virtual Worlds Enriching Innovation and Collaboration in Information
   Systems Research, Development, and Commercialisation
SO 2009 3RD IEEE INTERNATIONAL CONFERENCE ON DIGITAL ECOSYSTEMS AND
   TECHNOLOGIES
SE IEEE International Conference on Digital Ecosystems and Technologies
LA English
DT Proceedings Paper
CT 3rd IEEE International Conference on Digital Ecosystems and Technologies
CY JUN 01-03, 2009
CL Istanbul, TURKEY
SP IEEE
DE 3D Virtual Worlds; 3D Digital Ecosystems; Information systems research;
   research commercialisation and knowledge transfer
AB The increasing rate of technological development is changing how we interact socially, commercially, and politically, making this an exciting yet challenging time in which to live. As the pace of development is destabilising the status quo, it is increasingly important for individuals and organisations alike to adapt. Research, development, and commercialisation are important tools in facilitating innovation for organisations engaging in the modern knowledge/networked economy. As an emergent player in the networked economy, Digital Ecosystems have great potential for innovation. In particular 3D Virtual Worlds offer exciting opportunities for Information Systems research, development, and commercialisation. By their very structure, 3D Virtual Worlds such as Second Life provide a powerful context for innovation and collaboration: Second Life users are immersed in a 3D environment and empowered by a menu-based object-builder and a programming language; in-built text, voice, and body-language communication tools enrich communication, collaboration, and help provide a rich contextual presence. The community of users apply themselves to all realms of human endeavour, from recreational socialisation to systems development and entrepreneurial ventures. The current paper describes a university research commercialisation systems development project (of an Automated Essay Grading system called MarkIT), that utilises a 3D Digital Ecosystem for both promotion and implementation. Subsequently, this paper discusses the benefits, limitations, and suggestions for future innovation in research, development, and commercialisation of Information Systems incorporating 3D Virtual Worlds.
C1 [Dreher, Carl; Reiners, Torsten; Dreher, Naomi; Dreher, Heinz] Curtin Univ Technol, Perth, WA 6845, Australia.

PT S
AU Pattanaik, D
   Chatterjee, J
AF Pattanaik, Debashis
   Chatterjee, Jayanta
GP IEEE
TI Socio-technical Innovation and the Role of Conversation in a Digital
   Ecosystem for Agricultural Extension Services in India
SO 2009 3RD IEEE INTERNATIONAL CONFERENCE ON DIGITAL ECOSYSTEMS AND
   TECHNOLOGIES
SE IEEE International Conference on Digital Ecosystems and Technologies
LA English
DT Proceedings Paper
CT 3rd IEEE International Conference on Digital Ecosystems and Technologies
CY JUN 01-03, 2009
CL Istanbul, TURKEY
SP IEEE
DE Digital ecosystem; Knowledge; Innovation; Socio-technical change; DEAL;
   Community networks
AB Large and complex socio-technical systems like the agricultural extension services of (the multi-lingual, multi-cultural and heterogeneous societies) India, pose many challenges for creating an innovation system. The challenges stem from the multiplicity of social learning systems needed as well as due to the deep rooted heritage of age old "successful" technical systems that now need to embrace new practices arising from new research and due to emergence of new seeds, new pests and diseases, new scarcities and new competition. Social science and particularly the sociological understanding of social change can and must integrate with information system theories to address the complex challenge of innovation in Indian agricultural system. This paper analyses the challenges and presents a compilation of action reports from the implementation of the Digital Ecosystem for Agriculture and Rural Livelihood (DEAL) project that was initiated in northern India. In this process this paper explores how the emerging digital technologies can support collaborative knowledge creation and sharing and discuss the social landscape of socio-technical innovation and community networks.
C1 [Pattanaik, Debashis] Indian Inst Technol, Media Lab, Kanpur 208016, Uttar Pradesh, India.
   [Chatterjee, Jayanta] Indian Inst Technol, Dept IME, Kanpur 208016, Uttar Pradesh, India.
RP Pattanaik, D (reprint author), Indian Inst Technol, Media Lab, Kanpur 208016, Uttar Pradesh, India.

PT S
AU Pattanaik, D
   Chatterjee, J
AF Pattanaik, Debashis
   Chatterjee, Jayanta
GP IEEE
TI Services Innovation - Digital Ecosystem Approach to Dissemination and
   Co-creation of Knowledge for Indian Agriculture Extension Services
SO 2009 IEEE INTERNATIONAL CONFERENCE ON AUTOMATION SCIENCE AND ENGINEERING
SE IEEE International Conference on Automation Science and Engineering
LA English
DT Proceedings Paper
CT IEEE International Conference on Automation Science and Engineering
CY AUG 22-25, 2009
CL Bangalore, INDIA
SP IEEE
AB Indian agriculture is today at a cross road. Many new diseases, pests and weeds affect the crops. Some old techniques, such as the copious use of irrigation, have resulted in top soil impoverishment. There is a need for innovative practices to be introduced at every stage of the Indian agriculture value chain. The current practices within the Indian Agricultural Extension Service (IAES) focus on a top down approach to services. It largely depends on a traditional F2F service model. This model focuses on instructional model of imparting knowledge to the farmers at the village level. Our past studies across several districts of Uttar Pradesh in India show lack of innovation across the entire IAES system and ill effect of group think. Innovation at the grass root level does not spread across the value chain due to unidirectional approach of the current IAES. In this context ICT provides an opportunity to enhance the service dominant co-creation and delivery in the extension system by providing a set of tools and techniques that are interoperable and easy to use. This paper explores how digital technology deployment projects need to distinguish between organizing explicit knowledge from agricultural experts and researchers (Gran Dhara) in knowledge repositories as opposed to acquisition of field knowledge from farmers, traders and other practitioners (Gana Gyan) through participative and circularity of communication.
C1 [Pattanaik, Debashis] Indian Inst Technol, OPAALS Project, Kanpur 208016, Uttar Pradesh, India.
   [Chatterjee, Jayanta] Indian Inst Technol, Dept Ind Management Engn, Kanpur 208016, Uttar Pradesh, India.
RP Pattanaik, D (reprint author), Indian Inst Technol, OPAALS Project, Kanpur 208016, Uttar Pradesh, India.

TI Research on Innovation Ecosystem in IT Industry

DE Innovation ecosystem; Learning process; Knowledge spillovers
AB With the increasing trend of globalization of competition, networking of innovation, and the commercialization of technology in an era of knowledge-based economy, the concept of innovation ecosystem brings forward. This paper firstly introduces the concept and the formation mechanism of innovation ecosystem, secondly explains and designs the structure of innovation ecosystem in IT industry, finally discusses the learning process of innovation ecosystem in industry from two aspects and put forwards some advices promoting innovation capability and innovation value.

TI The Innovation of Supply Network Based on Industrial Clusters
SO ICOSCM 2009 - PROCEEDINGS OF THE 3RD INTERNATIONAL CONFERENCE ON
   OPERATIONS AND SUPPLY CHAIN MANAGEMENT
SE Series of Operations and Supply Chain Management in China
LA English
DT Proceedings Paper
CT 3rd International Conference on Operations and Supply Chain Management
CY JUL 28-AUG 05, 2009
CL Wuhan, PEOPLES R CHINA
SP Wuhan Univ, Chinese Univ Hong Kong, Chongqing Univ, NSFC
DE industrial clusters; supply chain; supply chain network; game theory
ID CHAIN; DISRUPTION
AB The disruption of supply chain can cause serious result for firms, which has been studied over the years. A sound supply network is essential for a company to avoid the tragedy. Industrial clusters provide a business ecosystem for firms, where there are relatively rich resources of the supply chains, innovation companies, and skill pools, and firms can take the advantages of the clusters' resource to build his own supply networks. Applying supply networks to business practice based on the industrial clusters is an innovative solution in the supply chain management practice.

PT J
AU Carayannis, EG
   Campbell, DFJ
AF Carayannis, Elias G.
   Campbell, David F. J.
TI 'Mode 3' and 'Quadruple Helix': toward a 21st century fractal innovation
   ecosystem
SO INTERNATIONAL JOURNAL OF TECHNOLOGY MANAGEMENT
LA English
DT Article
DE mode 3 innovation ecosystem; quadruple helix; innovation networks;
   knowledge clusters; knowledge fractals; glocal; academic firm; knowledge
   swings; conceptual branding; knowledge weavers
ID RESEARCH-AND-DEVELOPMENT; UNIVERSITY; KNOWLEDGE; NETWORKS; SYSTEMS;
   DYNAMICS; AUSTRIA; SCIENCE; MARKET; FIRMS
AB 'Mode 3' allows and emphasises the co-existence and co-evolution of different knowledge and innovation paradigms: the competitiveness and superiority of a knowledge system is highly determined by its adaptive capacity to combine and integrate different knowledge and innovation modes via co-evolution, co-specialisation and co-opetition knowledge stock and flow dynamics. The 'Quadruple Helix' emphasises the importance of also integrating the perspective of the media-based and culture-based public. What results is an emerging fractal knowledge and innovation ecosystem, well-configured for the knowledge economy and society.
C1 [Carayannis, Elias G.] George Washington Univ, Sch Business, Dept Informat Syst & Technol Management, Washington, DC 20052 USA.

AU Bugeaud, F
   Soulier, E
AF Bugeaud, Florie
   Soulier, Eddie
BE CamarinhaMatos, LM
   Paraskakis, I
   Afsarmanesh, H
TI Services Systems to Leverage Innovators' Knowledge: The Telecoms
   Industry Case
SO LEVERAGING KNOWLEDGE FOR INNOVATION IN COLLABORATIVE NETWORKS
SE IFIP Advances in Information and Communication Technology
LA English
DT Proceedings Paper
CT 10th IFIP Working Conference on Virtural Enterprises
CY OCT 07-09, 2009
CL Thessaloniki, GREECE
SP IFIP WG 5 5
DE SSME; Service System; Innovation; Knowledge
AB Today, telecoms operators have to prove their innovation capacity. They address corporate customers which are involved in collaborative value networks. They implement a process of new services research in order to create adapted solutions. This process is linked to a collaborative and complex practice between diverse innovators. However there is no structured method to leverage this community's knowledge. Based on the SSME(1) discussions, we suggest enriching the telecoms innovation approaches by the representation and the simulation of "services systems". This paper also proposes the development of a collaborative tool to support this suggestion and the innovators' practices. Our approach is currently tested on a specific telecom service in the e-health domain which presents an interesting business ecosystem.
C1 [Bugeaud, Florie; Soulier, Eddie] Univ Technol Troyes, CNRS, ICD Tech CICO FRE 2848, F-10010 Troyes, France.

PT J
AU Muresan, M
AF Muresan, Mihaela
TI REGIONAL VIRTUAL PLATFORMS SUPPORTING THE ENTERPRISES' COMPETITIVENESS
   AND THE SUSTAINABLE DEVELOPMENT
SO METALURGIA INTERNATIONAL
LA English
DT Article
DE virtual platform; sustainable development; competitiveness; digital
   business ecosystem
AB The paper presents the ideas generated by a Romanian Research project "Knowledge management architecture in environmental, social and economic areas, designed to support the sustainable regional development strategy", financed under the national research budget. One major result of the project is represented by the development of a regional virtual platform as a driver for knowledge management and innovation. This virtual environment creates a space for integrating and articulating ideas and innovative solutions in a wide participative way. The platform represents an integrator and mediator for the regional business environment and main stakeholders, as well as a Connectivity channel for bridging other European and world networks and clusters. The global knowledge economy creates new challenges for the industrial space from at least two perspectives: tire development of knowledge products and services, and the increased enterprises' connectivity through complex networks integrating dynamic clusters. The enterprises have to cope with the quick technological changes, with complex organizational systems and with global networking requirements. Consequently, the major enterprise's needs focus oil innovation, in order to increase competitiveness in a sustainable way. In this context, the increased accessibility to the new technologies and innovative solutions, as well as the capacity to generate knowledge and innovation represent the major intangible assets of the global enterprise. The most of the industries, including the metallurgy, are already connected in networks of organizations, technologies, products and consumers, ensuring their visibility, and interactions oil the market. The capacity of increasing the partnerships and various associations represent a major success factor of the actual global enterprise. In the same time, the enterprises are concerned more about the global perspective than about the local one, and consequently have not always strong links with the local development. In this new perspective, the research team identified the gap between the local administration and the regional actors related to the sustainable regional development and proposed the rise of advanced ICT tools for creating a regional virtual platform for supporting the networking among the regional stakeholders and facilitating the development of regional knowledge base, for the benefit of the regional sustainable development. In this perspective, the business actors are more sensitive to the local environmental, economic and social issues, and could contribute to the regional strategy design, as main regional stakeholders. In the same time, the business area will take advantage of the open access to valuable regional knowledge repository and to other platforms, such as digital business ecosystems European platform.

TI A Study on the Impacting Factors of the Inter-organizational Learning
   Process in Enterprise Strategy Innovation Ecosystem
SO PROCEEDINGS OF THE 6TH INTERNATIONAL CONFERENCE ON INNOVATION AND
   MANAGEMENT, VOLS I AND II
LA English
DT Proceedings Paper
CT 6th International Conference on Innovation and Management
CY DEC 08-10, 2009
CL Pontificia Univ Catolica de Sao Paulo, Sao Paulo, BRAZIL
SP Wuhan Univ Technol, Yamaguchi Univ, UNU MERIT
HO Pontificia Univ Catolica de Sao Paulo
DE Enterprise strategy innovation ecosystem; Learning process; Structural
   equation modeling
AB Based on the analysis of the connotation and structure of enterprise strategy innovation ecosystem, this paper establishes the learning process dynamic model of the ecosystem, and in-depth analyzes the operation mode of the four modules: knowledge incubator, knowledge sharing ecosystem, knowledge base and knowledge transfer path. On the basis of the above stuffy, the paper try to explore the impacting factors of the learning process, namely, the learning environment factors, knowledge factors and the learning characteristics of members and use the structural equation modeling method to empirically research the impact relationship among the three variables.

BE Feuerlicht, G

TI Standardization as a Business Ecosystem Enabler
SO SERVICE-ORIENTED COMPUTING - ICSOC 2008 WORKSHOPS
SE Lecture Notes in Computer Science
LA English
DT Proceedings Paper
CT 6th International Conference on Service-Oriented Computing
CY DEC 01-05, 2008
CL Sydney, AUSTRALIA
DE Standardization; business model; service-oriented computing
ID INNOVATION
AB This paper reports research-in-progress that considers standardization as an enabler in business ecosystems. Based on issues encountered, we propose that: business model design is also critical for standards bodies; standards can separate competition from cooperation; standards employ rule-centric designs; and requirements specification and compliance checking are essential. The propositions are illustrated using a standards body with which we have been working.

PT J
AU Garnsey, E
   Leong, YY
AF Garnsey, Elizabeth
   Leong, Yuen Yoong
TI Combining Resource-Based and Evolutionary Theory to Explain the Genesis
   of Bio-networks
SO INDUSTRY AND INNOVATION
LA English
DT Article
DE Commercialization of technologies; biopharmaceutical networks; the
   entrepreneurial firm; resource-based theory; evolutionary theory;
   business ecosystem
ID FIRM
AB This paper examines new firms creating innovative networks to support their development in emerging industries. Resource-based and evolutionary theories are combined to explain the genesis of a new business ecosystem. Two case studies of biopharm ventures developing drugs against cancer showed how participants altered their selection environment as they enhanced their network's capability. Resource building took place at the firm and network level through collaborative business models involving innovative contractors. This approach uncovered previously unnoticed features of networks for drug development: resource asynchronies were found to be a stimulus to innovation in development networks, as in the Penrosean firm.
C1 [Garnsey, Elizabeth; Leong, Yuen Yoong] Univ Cambridge, Ctr Technol Management, Inst Mfg, Dept Engn, Cambridge CB2 1RX, England.
RP Garnsey, E (reprint author), Univ Cambridge, Ctr Technol Management, Inst Mfg, Dept Engn, Mill Lane, Cambridge CB2 1RX, England.
EM ewg11@cam.ac.uk

PT J
AU Gawer, A
   Cusumano, MA
AF Gawer, Annabelle
   Cusumano, Michael A.
TI How companies become platform leaders
SO MIT SLOAN MANAGEMENT REVIEW
LA English
DT Article
AB An industry platform involves not only one company's technology or service but also an ecosystem of complements to it that are usually produced by a variety of businesses. As a result, becoming a platform leader requires different business and technology strategies than those needed to launch a successful stand-alone product. Companies should decide early on whether they want to pursue a platform or a product strategy.
   The authors describe two fundamental approaches to building platform leadership, which they call "coring" and "tipping." "Coring" is using a set of techniques to create a platform by making a technology "core" to a particular technological system and market. When pursuing a coring strategy, would-be platform leaders should think about issues such as how to make it easy for third parties to provide add-ons to the technology and how to encourage third-party companies to create complementary innovations. Examples of successful coring include Google Inc. in Internet search and Qualcomm Inc. in wireless technology. However, the authors note, Qualcomm faces opposition from some companies in its business ecosystem. The authors cite EMC Corp.'s WideSky initiative in the early 2000s as an attempt at coring that did not succeed. EMC's competitors were not eager to adopt WideSky as a platform and instead supported an open-standards one managed through an industry association.
   "Tipping" is the set of activities that helps a company "tip" a market toward its platform rather than some other potential one. Examples of tipping include Linux's growth in the market for Web server operating systems; the Linux case study, the authors point out, demonstrates the power of a coalition of service providers and users to tip a market by supporting a particular platform. Another tipping strategy is for a company to bundle features from an adjacent market into its existing platform; the authors call this "tipping across markets.".
C1 [Gawer, Annabelle] Univ London Imperial Coll Sci Technol & Med, Tanaka Business Sch, London SW7 2AZ, England.
   [Cusumano, Michael A.] MIT, Sloan Sch Management, Cambridge, MA 02139 USA.
RP Gawer, A (reprint author), Univ London Imperial Coll Sci Technol & Med, Tanaka Business Sch, London SW7 2AZ, England.

PT J
AU Iyer, B
   Davenport, TH
AF Iyer, Bala
   Davenport, Thomas H.
TI Reverse engineering Google's innovation machine
SO HARVARD BUSINESS REVIEW
LA English
DT Article
AB Even among internet companies, Google stands out as an enterprise designed with the explicit goal of succeeding at rapid, profuse innovation. Much of what the company does is rooted in its legendary IT infrastructure, but technology and strategy at Google are inseparable and mutually permeable - making it hard to say whether technology is the DNA of its strategy or the other way around. Whichever it is, Iyer and Davenport, of Babson College, believe Google may well be the internet-era heir to such companies as General Electric and IBM as an exemplar of management practice.
   Google has spent billions of dollars creating its internet-based operating platform and developing proprietary technology that allows the company to rapidly develop and roll out new services of its own or its partners' devising. As owner and operator of its innovation "ecosystem," Google can control the platform's evolution and claim a disproportionate percentage of the value created within it. Because every transaction is performed through the platform, the company has perfect, continuous awareness of, and access to, the by-product information and is the hub of all germinal revenue streams.
   In addition to technology explicitly designed and built for innovation, Google has a well-considered organizational and cultural strategy that helps the company attract the most talented people in the land -and keep them working hard. For instance, Google budgets innovation into job descriptions, eliminates friction from development processes, and cultivates a taste for failure and chaos.
   While some elements of Google's success as an innovator would be very hard and very costly to emulate, others can be profitably adopted by almost any business.
C1 [Iyer, Bala; Davenport, Thomas H.] Babson Coll, Wellesley, MA USA.
RP Iyer, B (reprint author), Babson Coll, Wellesley, MA USA.
EM biyer@babson.edu; tdavenport@babson.edu

PT J
AU Garnsey, E
   Lorenzoni, G
   Ferriani, S
AF Garnsey, Elizabeth
   Lorenzoni, Gianni
   Ferriani, Simone
TI Speciation through entrepreneurial spin-off: The Acorn-ARM story
SO RESEARCH POLICY
LA English
DT Article
DE spin-off; technological speciation; parent-progeny; technological
   innovation
ID EMERGENCE; COMPANIES; STRATEGY; TECHNOLOGIES; PERFORMANCE; INNOVATION;
   KNOWLEDGE; CREATION; PRODUCT
AB Can the concept of speciation explain evidence on how technologies branch and advance? Can evidence on innovation through spin-off usefully inform the concept of speciation? These questions are addressed through a case study of detailed processes enabling the shift of technology to new domains of application. An innovative IT firm developed its own semiconductor technology to remedy supplier deficiencies but it required a joint venture with a completely new business model to adapt and move the technology into new market domains. We propose the concept of techno-organizational speciation to delineate this phenomenon. Competing perspectives on speciation (compatibility, niche and lineage approaches) are found to illuminate the evidence, while complementarities between these conceptual dimensions are revealed by the case. Causal processes uncovered include the following: (1) Techno-organizational speciation through spin-off may be needed to launch a dominant technical standard, compatible with multiple applications. (2) This can be achieved through niche creation from which develops a new business ecosystem. (3) Inherited knowledge together with organizationally based learning foster the branching and renewal of technological lineages. (C) 2007 Elsevier B.V. All rights reserved.

TI Research on Industrial Organization in the Regional Industrial
   Ecosystem: Interactive Co-evolution of Enterprises
SO 2008 INTERNATIONAL CONFERENCE ON MANAGEMENT SCIENCE & ENGINEERING
   (15TH), VOLS I AND II, CONFERENCE PROCEEDINGS
SE International Conference on Management Science and Engineering-Annual
   Conference Proceedings
LA English
DT Proceedings Paper
CT 15th International Conference on Management Science and Engineering
CY SEP 10-12, 2008
CL Long Beach, CA
SP Natl Nat Sci Fdn China, Harbin Inst Technol, Calif State Univ, State Univ Management, IEEE Technol Management Council
DE industrial organization; interactive co-evolution; regional industrial
   ecosystem; stability analysis; strategy
ID EVOLUTIONARY PERSPECTIVE; MULTILEVEL PERSPECTIVE; INNOVATIONS;
   TRANSITIONS; SYSTEMS
AB Based on ecological perspective, correlative enterprises in the same region constitute a regional industrial ecosystem. Analysis on industrial organization of the regional industrial ecosystem focuses mainly on interactive co-evolution of these correlative enterprises. This paper considers that the modes of interactive co-evolution of enterprises include reciprocal cooperation, adherent dependence and vehement competition, according to the analogy between operation of organizations in the economic system and species activities in the natural ecosystem. By qualitative analysis of differential equation and numerical simulation for these different modes of interactive co-evolution between enterprises, the paper demonstrates that reciprocal cooperation is beneficial to both sides of enterprises, adherent dependence is helpful to growth of small enterprises, and one-side-benefit vehement competition is contributed to development of large enterprises. In the end, results further reveal the mechanism of interactive co-evolution among enterprises and help forecast the evolution about industrial organization in the regional industrial ecosystem.
C1 [Zhang Rui; Qian Xing-san] Shanghai Univ Sci & Technol, Sch Management, Shanghai 200093, Peoples R China.

TI The Research of the RTIE Performance by Using the Projection Pursuit

ID DATA ENVELOPMENT ANALYSIS
AB Since the regional technology innovation system is an open system that is away from equilibrium, nonlinear, layered and fluctuant, and has the characters of ecosystem, we will regard the technology innovation system as a technology innovation ecosystem. Based on the concept of regional technology innovation ecosystem (RTIE), we set up the evaluation indicator system to analysis the performance of input and output of technology innovation in 30 Chinese regions by using Projection-Pursuit model. As a result of the statistical technology's overcoming the impact of abnormal points, we get better evaluation conclusion. So it is a reasonable method for Projection-Pursuit model to evaluate the regional technology innovation ecosystem performance.

TI Risk Analysis of Multi-participant Service Innovation's Platform
SO ADVANCES IN MANAGEMENT OF TECHNOLOGY, PT 2
LA English
DT Proceedings Paper
CT International Conference on Management of Technology
CY 2008
CL Taiyuan, PEOPLES R CHINA
SP Shanxi Prov Assoc Risk Management, Shanxi Univ Finance & Econ
DE service innovation platform; multi-participant; risk analysis
AB In the era of service economic, the innovation service companies begin to real time innovation by using their powerful platform network such as IBM, Google, Online game, and so on. It becomes the innovation "ecosystem" based on the multi-participants' integration of enterprise, customer and the third party. The service innovation platform is positive interaction and positive cycle for various main bodies to gain more advantages. It is a innovation way bringing the new service pattern and the new profit growth source for the enterprise from bottom to top. However, it's the key factor for the strategy of multi-participants' service innovation whether the risk of the service innovation platform is evaluated and managed or not. The paper analyzed the characteristics of the service innovation platform and the outline of the risk. It puts forward the risk elusion methods to success of service inonvation in the constructing of the service innovation platform.
